Comment: Not entirely true. Yes, my employer pays a portion of my group insurance. If he didn't, I would likely have more money in my paycheck, which would make health insurance more affordable ... though personally, I would prefer to put that money in invested savings or a HSA so I could afford actual medical care. Health insurance does me no good if the deductible is ridiculous. Being mandated to have insurance and paying a portion of premiums under current conditions means I don't have any room in my budget to actually spend toward actual medical care.

You see the death spiral? Obamacare was a STUPID idea that has made medical care increasingly unaffordable except for a narrow slice of the population that qualifies for Medicaid, who must now stand in a long line waiting for treatment that we who can't afford medical care because we make too much money have to pay for.

It's ridiculous!

Comment: While these are not new issues we also have to be careful in that we have to acknowledge between when Skype might be an appropriate option and when it is not.  Those in the community that need the services the most are the ones that are at risk during this divisive strike. Medical appointments, mental health issues, job interviews and some very sensitive needs cannot be placed in the Skype category.  There is a lot to do to ensure that the Deaf, deafened and hard of hearing community is able to play on a level field.  Take 911 access for example; while a hearing person can simply dial 911 and gain access to emergency services - those with a hearing loss cannot. We fall way behind in equal access in many ways.  As far as I can recall - access is defined by those that have the disability according to The Human Rights Code - not by those who manage the agency. If Skype is not for me I should be allowed to make that known and present my preference for access to uphold my dignity, my right.

Comment: From the top of Wolverine Peak (Chugach Mts.) I once spotted an approaching climber far below through my binoculars. The weather clouds were already working their way along the high ridge toward me but it was still sunny. The young man was wearing a tank top and had nothing more. Also, he was a redhead...and I could swear his exposed skin was already turning red from exposure to the brilliant sun. I was way too far away to shout a warning. He just kept on coming...and the weather as well. Then it hit. Hailed so hard I had to stand over my pack dog to shield her from the slashing, wind-driven deluge. Thunder and lightning as well. Didn't last long. I glassed to see how the redheaded fellow in the tank top was doing. The hail was just getting to his position. Hasty retreat would describe his actions. And yes, that was all he had on his upper body...a tank top. I felt his pain! I also did a retreat of sorts. Decided to camp well-off the peak itself. Lightning and all...

Comment: So you think Quintillion, a for-profit company, has hired Alcatel Lucent and is spending billions on the Arctic Fiber cable to bring internet to a few remote communities on Alaska's west and north coasts? Doubtful.

Arctic Fiber is a way to cut microseconds off of trading algorithms buy and sell times between Japan and European stock exchanges by using the most direct route possible by cutting across the Arctic Ocean. It's financed by banks and big financial trading firms, especially Cooper Investment Partners. Alaska happens to be on the way, and Quintillion in their wisdom have secured federal subsidies to run offshoots from the cable to connect these local communities... it is also good PR to do this, and the cable benefits by power injection at regular intervals as well. But the notion that Arctic Fiber is being installed solely for these communities is laughable.

So my fact-based comments seem asinine to you (meaning "stupid or foolish") -- how do you figure?

Comment: Question: Should the Westboro Baptist Church in Kansas have the right to go to a graphic art designer (who is gay)and have him design and produce "professional art graphics" that "professionally" portray their anti-gay rhetoric? -

In one case, they ruled that one baker could not decline to decorate a "gay wedding cake" while in another case, they ruled that a baker could refuse to decorate a "anti-gay cake." Comment: I know that before the last referendum there were "town halls" with people fielding questions and explaining proportional representation.  Even with this effort, many people felt that they didn't understand what a government would be like....how it would be different.

Recently a friend explained to me (she had lived in a country who elected leaders through proportional representation) that the parties co-operated with each other and formed coalitions.  We need real education on what a government would be like in British Columbia if such a change takes place.

Something has to change...one person..heading one party, has far too much power to make decisions that impact us so completely.  Maybe there would be more dialogue with the proposed change.

Comment: From what I've read, Ivereigh and Winters are talking about hermeneutics, the science of interpretation. This is also at the bottom of the Spadaro article, which is part of why many people objected to it.

One theory describes a dialectical imagination and an analogical imagination. Dialectical, from dialogue, implies a belief that God has spoken and we rely on written accounts of that speech. Faith is in a set of propositions that we adhere to. The emphasis is on taking something in from another, on books and writing. 

The analogical, or sacramental, imagination sees things as like, or unlike, other things. Ideas are conveyed by stories, pictures, people, statues. These help express ideas that are difficult to express in dogmatic words.

Comment: The lower dam was apparently plugged by rafting up logs then submerging them by piling rock on them, to form a latticework plug, of sorts, so why not just dredge them out and let the river flow under the dam, then install a gate to store water for times of drought? The upper dam could have been similarly drilled under to allowed the lakes to refill in flood season, protecting downstream property and then used as a reservoir in Summer. We spent millions of scarce tax dollars for the aesthetics of a "wild" canyon for a few tourists. Once the lakes were drained the dams could collapse in an earthquake with no real harm done, but would likely stand if a seismic sensor automatically opened the drains if things started rocking. Now we have to spend millions more each year repairing flood damage and building new reservoirs, which will likely have their own hazards, and the animals and birds that had come to rely on those lakes for habitat had to move on or die. Idiots R Us. Your tax $ @ jerk.

Comment: DOR doesn't do the transfer to the dividend account. 

Page 8 of the decision:
"In May 2016 the legislature passed an appropriation bill that included an
estimated $1.362 billion transfer from APFC’s earnings reserve to DOR’s dividend fund,
consistent with prior practice and the statutory formula. But in June Governor Bill
Walker exercised his line-item veto power and reduced the estimated $1.362 billion
transfer to $695.65 million. The legislature met in July but did not vote to override the
governor’s veto. This resulted in 2016 Permanent Fund dividend payments of $1,022
to eligible Alaskans, about half of what had been expected under the legislature’s
appropriation.

Comment: Mokantx, quick note.

The "Instructions for Diocesan Synods" issued by the Cong. for Bishops and the Cong. for the Evangelization of Peoples goes to great pains to make clear that the bishop governs.  Quotes:

The purpose of the diocesan Synod is to assist the Bishop in the exercise of the office proper to him, namely, that of governing the Christian community.

This purpose determines the particular roles to be ascribed to those priests who partake in the work of the Synod "as wise collaborators with the Order of Bishops, their helpers and chosen instruments, and who are called to serve the People of God"[5]. The Synod also offers the Bishop the opportunity of calling to cooperate with him and with his priests some members of the laity as well as some chosen religious.

Thus any attempt to place the Synod in opposition to the Bishop on the grounds of "representation of the People of God" is contrary to the authentic order of ecclesial relations.

Comment: I'm no fan of the guy, but this is not Mayor Moonbeam's fault.  The GVRD doesn't get enough snow most winters to justify the investment that would be required in Toronto or Montréal for plowing, salting, sanding, etc., and ratepayers would be up in arms if MM proposed it.

It's difficult to see winter tires as the solution, since for most of the winter Lower Mainland drivers only need to worry about rain.  But what about tire chains?  They are easy to install on short notice and easy to remove, and they work really well when the street turns into a skating rink.

Ah, but I suppose most motorists haven't a clue how to put chains on, or take them off, and they're probably too lazy for the most part to do it.  Well, maybe it's time to learn!

Comment: People who have unpleasant experiences in life that impact our mind and body, they usually get Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). They are recurring flashbacks, avoiding thoughts or people associated with the traumatic event, or numbing of memories of the event, and hyperarousal. Physically they might get headaches, muscle tension and pain, chest pain, fatigue, changes in sex drive, upset stomach, sleep problems and urinary disorders. Yoga is a great solution to deal with these psychological and physical problem. Practicing yoga can help them to stay in the present and focus on what is happening now rather than the past and it ultimately keep them more stable and calm. Comment: Not sure how long ago the out-flow of Grant Lake changed into the present channel near south end; but it has at some point as indicated by two turbulent areas that look to be large waterfalls which may have slowed salmon & trout from getting into that lake.
.
The original channel can be seen in google earth, as other older channels from flood stage outflow along the escarpment above (middle) Trail Lake; those perhaps from glacier thaw some hundred+ years ago. Evidence in rock can be harder to gauge, erosion may take longer to happen if the rock were harder than guessed.
.
The last time my travels were to the south end of Grant Lake, was March 1985 when I had a new Yamaha Bravo with incredible MPG & oil injection. After chem spill at C.P. RR siding. Three of us went up there in deep powder. A wall-tent on wooden platform was by Grant Creek headwaters. 
.
Previous visits had been on snowshoes; summer hikes, & notable one, on low-powered trailbike; early 1970s old mine via road/swamp.

Comment: Just taking corn in Nebraska and turning it into the 10% alcohol for automobiles has had that effect already... especially in third-world countries.  

"In 2000, over 90% of the U.S. corn crop went to feed people and livestock, many in undeveloped countries, with less than 5% used to produce ethanol. In 2013, however, 40% went to produce ethanol, 45% was used to feed livestock, and only 15% was used for food and beverage (AgMRC)."

"The grain required to fill a 25-gallon gas tank with ethanol can feed one person for a year, so the amount of corn used to make that 13 billion gallons of ethanol will not feed the almost 500 million people it was feeding in 2000. This is the entire population of the Western Hemisphere outside of the United States."

The law of unintended consequences cannot be repealed!

https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamesconca/2014/04/20/its-final-corn-ethanol-is-of-no-use/#6eeea60667d3

Comment: Is it possible that humans are not the primary cause of climate change? Well, not really. We know that, due to "natural forcings", the planet should be cooling; but it isn't. The 45% increase in CO2 in the last century is the only credible explanation for the observed warming, and it is incontrovertible that humans are the cause for the 45% increase in CO2. 
Is it possible that "climate science is tainted by politics and money?" Well, not really. ALL the evidence shows warming; from temperature records to sea level rise to melting ice masses, etc. There IS NO evidence that the chief cause of the observed warming is other than human activity, and the main money in the game is on the side of trying to cast doubt on the scientific consensus, mostly from the petroleum industry and its enablers. So yes; the evidence for human-based climate change is so overwhelming that it is foolish to think otherwise.

Comment: As a cyclist myself,  would not make the claim that car use is a leading cause of death. Please don't take one person's views as representing all cyclists, just as I would not do the same regarding motorists.
Some cyclists are arrogant, to which I say: "It's hard to carry a cross when cycling". 
The alternative is to appreciate how many motorists are simply stuck in their cars due to planning that requires sprawl.  Sure, there are those cyclists that are willing to ride 20 miles a day to commute or families that raise children without a car. But their exception should not be a critique of everyone who drives a car. 
For the most part, people who bike really like it. No one has to ride on a rainy 35 degree day. But there is so much independence, exhilaration, and exposure to nature that for me at least, having to drive is the depressing experience.
The best benefit is from riding those two miles that most people drive. A cold engine uses 30% more fuel but a two mile ride is doable.

Comment: David makes a good point. If the Tokitae is the problem, then it seems a second ferry of equal size would only make things worse. On the other hand, I'm not aware of any requirement that prohibits ferries from leaving before they are fully loaded. Many people reported that happening last year. Perhaps ferries just needs to be more rigid with its schedule keeping, requiring the larger boats to maintain the 30-minute schedule no matter what. That way they'd at least do the same job as the 124s but still be capable of taking on more cars when possible. Even if they only had time to load 10 more cars per load as opposed to the full 20, that's still 10 less riders waiting at the dock. 
I wonder if the larger Olympic-class boats are really slower, and did actually transport fewer cars last year. Good questions for sure, ones that I'll ask!
—Justin Burnett, editor

Comment: About 30 years ago decisions were made to move mental health patients from the hospital in Salem to "community based solutions." Cases were made for it, but there were very few community-based options and no money was allocated to create or give incentives to organizations to build and operate them. 
I was on a board of a mental health organization in another county at that time. Our organization operated a very small facility, but we knew we couldn't handle the extras who would come to our community. Nevertheless, patients were released with no good options in communities they went to.
Decisions are made by politicians and bureaucrats, but they don't have all the information they need and their goals may not be in the best interest of the patients who are turned out into communities; endangering the patients and at times others. 
A closing date of 2018 doesn't allow much time for planning, does it?

Federal logging has nearly doubled since the Great Recession which isn't exactly "discontinued" or "little or no" federal forest management.

Comment: >'limited, democratic socialism'
I used that term as a kind of catch-all as there are many kinds of systems that I would be happy with- it excludes the dictatorial attempts like North Korea or the old Iron Curtain countries. It doesn't get rid of a market economy - but it does have social assistance to ensure a minimum standard of living, strong regulation to prevent the rich from literally murdering millions of the poor (as they do with extreme alacrity when unchecked).
What exact form it takes though is not set in stone, I think local conditions should alter the specifics. The social democracies of Western Europe are good, Canada and New Zeeland are good. But so is Argentina where 80% of the population is employed in worker-owned co-ops that are democratically managed. 

Ultimately -I want empirically tested results, I want a world without poverty, without hunger, without homelessness. And there is absolutely no practical reason why we couldn't live in one already.

Comment: The behind-closed-doors negotiating by the legislature on rail funding underscores the need for the Sunshine Law to apply to the legislature, which is now exempt from it.  The Sunshine Law states,  "Opening up the governmental process to public scrutiny and participation is the only viable and reasonable method of protecting the public interest....[T]he formation  and conduct of public policy  -- the discussions, deliberations, decisions, and actions of governmental agencies -- should be conducted as openly as possible."  Apparently, the decision about how to continue to fund rail will be made through private meetings, and the purpose of the special session is only to rubber stamp that decision.  The public will never know the real reasons behind it. That's no way to run a democracy.

Comment: Some facts about  languages: 

Mandarin is the most spoken language in the world; however, English is the most widely spoken language ( note the difference) followed by Spanish.

In China, as in many countries, English is now a mandatory second language.

Chinese has about a dozen major variations with Mandarin the major variation ( Some people incorrectly call these variations " dialects"). The type of Mandarin spoken around Beijing is now the official language of China. And, those Chinese characters you see:, they are called "Hanzi". Even though the major types of the Chinese language are mutually incomprehensible to the listener,  the Hanzi  character set is understood by all people who speak  Chinese. That  is why they will  never disappear because these characters serve to unite the Chinese mainland. A Cantonese speaker won't understand a Hakka speaker, but they still can communicate using the Hanzi. Something like a Chinese Esperanto.

Comment: I would suggest that the current crossing safety measures are very adequate WITHOUT the train horns.  The issue is not that individuals don't know a train is coming.  The barriers are "down", the lights are flashing, the bells are ringing.  Persons who are struck by trains at such crossing knowingly disregard the existing warnings and barriers.  They're in a hurry and don't want to wait for "that damn train", so they drive around the barrier, ride their bike around it, or walk around it......after all they will "beat" the train to the crossing.  Breaking news: at such crossings the "tie" always goes to the train.

Those loud, obnoxious horns are appropriate and needed at rural crosssing where there are no barriers and,often, are no signals.  Having trains sound those horns at each crossing in a city is unnecessary.  Requiring millions of dollars to "up-grade" the crossings is unnecessary.  What's necessary?.......that people quit being so "stupid" in decisions to ignore the warnings...

Comment: Definition of 'Monopoly' Definition: A market structure characterized by a single seller, selling a unique product in the market. In a monopoly market, the seller faces no competition, as he is the sole seller of goods with no close substitute. 

Our cab industry has had a monopoly for years. There is only two companies in the city who use their power to feed off the customers. They offer poor service for their price and less accountability for their drivers. Uber offers better service and innovation for customers. Ubers customers have been happier with Uber for awhile now and have requested uber as opposed to cabbies. Customers deserve a choice as they are footing the bill.

As with all investments there is risk. Mine took a hit during the 2008 recession. Investing in a permit is similar and a higher priced risk at that. They stated they felt for the cabbies at the assembly meeting but they will have to take the hit.Customers want Uber and its only Fair for the customer to have option

Comment: I don't think Fikile wrote this, but whoever did has done a rather astute job at pointing out the failures of the Mbeki/Manuel-led era. It of course cannot provide a defence to #ZuptaGate, but I think it's of interest to note that state corruption has been a hallmark of our country since its inception. The Guptas are by far the most brazen of the lot so far, but to look back on the Mbeki or even Mandela eras with rose-tinted glasses I think would equally be ill-advised. The rot set in years and years ago. Sadly the ANC has never been about clean governance. Of course that doesn't take away from the abject scandal of our current failed state, but it did serve to remind me that our 'stalwarts' and 'constitutionalists' have as much of a case to answer as the thieves and Zupta acolytes of today. A bit like looking at Trump and longing for Bush methinks.

Comment: I just read the Brooks article.   I came away with a better understanding of the man Netanyahu, than I've learned through a decade news reports.  I don't believe that Brooks loves or hates Netanyahu.   I believe that he knows all human beings are a mixed bag of good and bad impulses, all of which have to be understood in the broader context of one's social relationships.   

In other words Brooks is fascinated by the nature of many people and is purposeful in his desire to give the reader an interesting portrait, without excessive judgement from him.  

I think it is interesting to see Brooks move from conservative columnist to simply being a very good writer.  Honestly most people only see one facet of the people they meet, the one filtered by our own bias.   A writer of Brooks caliber helps broaden our sight.

Comment: The other factor at play in America, more than in Canada, is that some people resent feeling liable for the health care of fellow citizens who are relatively indifferent to the perils of things like bad food, risky sexual practices, use of tobacco, alcohol or other drugs..  
I'm not arguing that this resentment is altogether rational, because it is not clear that these risky practices result in higher lifetime health care costs.  
However, in my anecdotal surveys, it is a factor that seems to figure more prominently in the minds of Americans than it does with Canadians, and that may have something to do with the higher levels of sin taxes levelling the balance of accounts in Canada.

Comment: To bring perspective to what the Marine National Monument Expansion means for Hawaii/US fishing industry, one has to look at two agreements and what it means for tuna conservancy. One is NAFTA and the other is Western Central Pacific Fisheries Commission (WCPFC).  

Earlier this year the US was in dispute with the WCPFC over the US's $1.1 million dollar license to participate in the Forum Fisheries Agency tuna conservation Vessel Day Scheme. Conveniently, the US is also expanding its territorial reach with not only Papahanaumokuakea, but also across the Pacific among all it's territories and military outposts.  The entire Pacific Remote Islands Marine National Monument (PRIMNM) will reach nearly 2 million sq. kilometers to be managed by the DOI and DOD.  This will interfere with other Pacific fishing fleets who are part of the WCPFC.

Also the US already has fishing privileges in Mexico's EEZ under NAFTA. This is why you can get sushi and poki bowls almost everywhere in the US for chea

Comment: JJ, Tchnically under Article XI Section 15 it would be considered an unfunded mandate but it may not reach the threshold established in that section for legal action. It probably would not really cost the county much as we already provide fall protection on lifts and other areas, I can not think of where it would cost us much more than changing our safety rule book for employees from 10' to 6' about use of safety harnesses and fall protection. I would note that the costs of the two programs we will be talking about also include indirect costs of increases in contracts with many of the non-profits that provide many of our human services that have many part-time and minimum wage employees. Multiply that times 36 counties and 200+ incorporated cities in Oregon and it adds up to a pretty big unfunded mandate. (Just one of the reasons the Legislature skipped sending this to Ways and Means as it should have.) This is worth the time to at least discuss it.

Comment: "Trudeau isn't doing so poorly"

There's lots of angles to attack this one, but one example will suffice: marijuana legalization.  

The LPC 'legalized marijuana' by downloading the responsibility for enforcement, policy and standards to the provinces, but nonsensically retained federal criminal legislation for sale to minors, introducing a guaranteed conflict between the provincial right to set age of majority and federal enforcement of that law.  Are we really going to get into the business of arresting people and putting them in FEDERAL prison for selling to an 18 year old in Ontario, when that 18 year old can cross over into Quebec and buy it perfectly legally?  It's what already happens with alcohol, but we're talking fines at the provincial level for alcohol, not felony convictions like we would with pot.

It's juvenile legislation that got rushed so the feds had a chance of getting it out in the public's eyes by 420. It's that kind of 'optics first' thinking that's so idiotic.

Comment: Do you own small mixed-use rental premises, perhaps including residential units above commercial storefronts? In the large rental complex in which I live municipal taxes have declined in at least 3 of the most recent 7 years. We get notices from the city about this because under provincial law a portion of such decreases is passed on to tenants in the form of fractionally reduced rents. This situation appears to be a function of the assessment system whereby in an overheated housing market the assessed valuations for other forms of commercial and residential property use are rising faster than the assessed valuations for dedicated rental housing properties. However, there's been a particularly problematic rise in low-rise commercial assessments, resulting in tax increases in the range of 200 to 400 percent as I understand it, in some areas in downtown Toronto, which has become a contentious political issue resulting in a "tax revolt" by some commercial property owners.

Comment: Rick M

Thanks for the reply. 

First I will mention that the price you are quoting for milk in the US is for ‘organic’ milk. 

The price for regular 2% is lower. $3.33 US. Still, after exchange, not that much different than Canada. 

Since I live in northern BC, I don’t see US dairy prices that often. My last real experience with US dairy pricing was in 2013 on a trip through Idaho and Washington state. At the time I remember buying and freezing as much cheese as we could fit into the freezer of our RV. Cheese was less than half the price we were paying in B.C., and this was with the dollar at par. 

I remember milk prices being attractive, but I can’t remember how much so. We couldn’t fit much in our RV, and my wife and I could only drink so much before it went sour. 

For the record, it isn’t that I didn’t believe one-eighty, but if one is making claims, it helps to back it up with a link just so we all know what is said is valid, like your posts do.

Comment: Just some fun fact checking on your funny facts:

Republican leaning states receive more tax dollars than they pay: True only if you include military expenditures, which the state has little say in, and if you include social security and medicare recipients, who have arguably paid in what they're getting back.

Your typical welfare recipient is most likely to be a rural white Republican: Not true. 40% of welfare recipients are white (while whites are 63% of the population), meaning "your typical welfare recipient" is likely not-white.

93 of 100 poorest counties are in red states: True if you use income to define what's "poor". But most are in rural areas with substantially lower costs of living than urban areas.

If you are really arguing that the poorest counties are "poor" (low income) because they vote Republican, then you can also say welfare recipients are on welfare because they vote Democratic.

Comment: Charles Hartzell - The Constitution Budget Reserve (CBRF) was set in 1990 with voter approval. All money received by the State after July 1, 1990, through resolution of disputes about the amount of certain mineral-related income, must be deposited in the CBRF. The Legislature may, under certain conditions, appropriate funds from the CBRF to fund the operations of state government. The Twenty-First Legislature created a subaccount within the CBRF (Subaccount) effective July 1, 2000 which was liquidated on April 1, 2015 with the balance being transferred to the Main Fund. http://treasury.dor.alaska.gov/Investments/Constitutional-Budget-Reserve.aspx
It takes a super-majority to access the CBRF and the Democrats last year refused to allow the liquidation until special session. The Democrats are using it for political leverage to get things they want, like expanded Medicare, education, health & social services. Meanwhile DOT has seen an 18% reduction in funding.

Comment: Dennis (et al.) 

I think there's some truth to that, though I suspect that many who may have suspected something was going on, likely really didn't want to go any deeper, and  likely never really knew.  SHOULD they have aske questions? Of course.  We see things so much clearer in hindsight: I just hope in the future, if we have suspicions, we ask, we get involved.

That still leaves the problem of church leadership that remains all words, and so little action.  Sacking a few bishops won't sink the church, nor will it really do all that much to change what's out there.  But it WILL send two messages.  The one is to those who are still tempted to look the other way.  Those in power cannot be allowed to look the other way, so sacking a few would be a good message to send.  But of even more importance, is the message that this would send to the laity: a laity that longs for a "we hear you" message.  Apologies without actions are corrosive.  Convicting a bishop who is a pedophile won't do.

Comment: The Eucharist was given to us, for us.  This was Jesus' 'ministry of the table' which affirms just how much Jesus has been a lover of life, a saver of life, and a giver of life.  This ministry of meals continues in the Eucharist, called by the first Christians by those beautiful names 'the Breaking of Bread' and 'the Lord's Supper'.

The early Christians understood that it was the Risen Lord himself who was calling them to get together to celebrate all he meant to them, and that is was he himself who led them in their celebrations from start to finish.
------
Philppe Rouilard, 'From Human Meal to Christian Eucharist,' LIVING BREAD, SAVING CUP: Readings on the Eucharist, ed. R.K. Seasoltz [Collegeville, MN: Liturgical Press, 1987]

Donald Senior, JESUS, A GOSPEL PORTRAIT [New York/Mahwah NJ: Paulist Press, 1992] p. 63--This emphasis on table fellowship is notable in a semitic culture where sharing meal was considered more a sharing of life than simply a casual association.

Comment: .

I took the survey.

It was simple, easy to understand and fill out.

It hardly touched on the issue of the ballot - FPTP, Preferred/Ranked Ballot or Proportional Representation.

It read to me as if it was designed to determine general priorities of survey respondents rather than their ballot preferences.

All this criticism from the opposition is just a lot of hot air.

The CPC wants FPTP because they will never be able to pull in the support of a majority of voters with a ranked ballot or PR and will likely see their seat share shrink.

The NDP wants PR because it will likely increase their seat share.

The Liberals want ranked ballot because, where they are not first choice, they will always be second choice and thus gain seats.

None of the options are perfect.

Which is the least imperfect?

Comment: If you want to plan an economy, you need to have some idea (preferably a strong one) of what's happening on the ground in terms of production, distribution, and effective demand, so that your planning board can nudge the economy in the "right" direction (ideally, in the direction determined by the general public, whether that's a more equitable distribution of existing resources or more efficient use of them). Price signals are essentially imperfect representations of real-time interactions within the economy. My question is this: why do we need price signals at all in an era of just-in-time production models, consumer meta-data, RFID chips, satellite tracking, and so on? I’m not necessarily endorsing Lange (or refuting his opponents), but rather trying to point out that our organizational capacity (our ability to plan the economy, if we wanted to) is contingent on the development of productive forces (i.e. technology).

Comment: Exactly.  This is known as the "free-rider problem" in economics.  It has been well demonstrated that  free common goods (in this case, health care which feels "free") leads to over consumption and under production.  Too much of this and the system implodes.

To protect the common good in question, governments need to mitigate the free-rider problem by a) some sort of user fee or co-pay or tax, and/or b) regulation/rules.

I'm an advocate for a careful implementation of a version of option (a).  Regulation/rules on how health care can be used and when it cannot is very undesirable, in my view.

Comment: Actually, piggy-backing semi trailers has long been a part of the trucking industry. Unfortunately, this more-efficient practice was stalled when Reagan deregulated trucking. With our current shortage of drivers willing to do demanding long-haul work for such meager wages (used to be on the high side of middle class, now it's better than barista, but not worth the health problems that come with it) I expect to see piggy-backing make a small come-back before it is displaced by Uber's autonomous trucks. Also let's not forget containers loaded onto trucks at the docks.

As far as our fires go, there is a dramatic difference between the wetter conditions of yesteryear, when it wasn't so bad to let them burn until the rains started again (rarely more than six weeks time) and today's hotter, drier conditions. The fires now burn faster, start earlier in the year and don't go out until later in the year. It's time we learned to put them out.

Comment: First you need to decide what you want to achieve, then build an appropriate system.   The blind trust issue is likely to deter well-qualified candidates - is that a desirable outcome?  I don’t think so...  So what is a reasonable alternative?  ‘Reasonable’ is important.  IPPs are an existing (but not well known) product.  Other firms than Morneau’s could provide it.  If the product can address some of the issues in the small business tax spat, it would be irresponsible for the Minister to not refer to it!  Yes, he might benefit a bit through his firm, but unlikely by a large amount.  What is needed is a way to identify the issue, then decide how important it is, and monitor the outcome.  Taken to extremes, you could say anything a political figure says or does could affect the markets - does that mean they should only be allowed to hold cash?!  Why should their small business holdings be exempt?  It’s complicated and reducing it to an oversimplified statement is not helpful.

Comment: Family Trusts are often testamentary trusts, bequeathed at death from tax-paid money.  There is no tax dodge here.  Instead of bequeathing money into the hands of minors and infants, a Trust is formed where ALL income each year must be distributed to beneficiaries by a responsible person - income remaining inside the trust is taxed at a the highest rate.  Trust tax rules have recently changed to become much less attractive from a tax perspective.  Sheer is a hypocrite on this one.  And, anyone can form such trusts on death.

Farmers and businesspeople who have large pools of capital captured in companies can do an estate freeze and transfer the newco to family members.  There are may ways to skin a cat.  

The idea that the proposed changes will cause every fat cat to suddenly freeze in their steps and take a big tax hit is ridiculous.  Anyone smart enough to form a personal corporation to sprinkle wealth is smart enough to find many new ways forward that will work under proposed laws.

Comment: Thank you Elkton for putting on a wonderful event and thank you  RG, and  Darling for the article and Eberhardt for the photos.  The Ft. Umpqua replica is very well done, as historically accurate as was feasible, and the sight of  it  with its red  Hudsons Bay Company flag is one of the amazing scenes on this beautiful drive to the coast.
  On a per capita basis Elkton must have more enthusiastic volunteers than any  other town in Oregon.  The event was capped off with its historic pageant which especially featured the finest bunch of kids that any town would be proud of.  For many visitors  who hadn't known of England's control of Oregon through its forts, this was an eye opener as long buried history came alive.  

If there was any imperfection to a grand event, it was that Ft. Umpqua's role as as  the British Hudsons Bay Company's  "Bastion of Empire" and fur collecting center was somewhat lost in the hubub of living history characters and purveyors of American souvenir trinkets.

Comment: I know people on ODSP, which is basically a fund which does not pay enough to help someone live a comfortable or dignified life with a disability, while also traping them in the cycle of being a complete slave to the cheque that comes ever couple of weeks.  because of their disabilities they cannot work a 40 hr week (though they regularly put in 20 hrs), they pay 50% of their paycheck back to the disability fund, they pay income tax on the ODSP money they receive, and they can't save money to invest in anything that would help them break the cycle (they are legally bound not to).  Which means they are stuck in it for eternity.  A program like this basic income would help tremendously with that and help people live dignified lives.  I fully support it, especially after having spoken to people who have dissabilities (and they are varied).  This is the exact reason people pay taxes and I couldnt think of a better way to help those most in need in our society.

Comment: The only reason for the parents to blame the school it to increase the pot of money for a suit and to deflect blame from themselves. Having worked in commercial insurance for nearly two decades, I saw a few suits in which the parents took businesses to court when they--the parents--were primarily responsible for their losses. The worst case involved a couple who had been separated. They met in a hotel to "work things out," enjoying a few drinks at a bar next to the hotel's indoor pool while their 6 year old son swam in the pool.  Although there were signs informing guests that there were no lifeguards on duty and that children under 12 must be accompanied by a responsible adult, the parents left their son alone in the pool as they went to a hotel room to "work things out."  The boy drowned.  The parents sued the hotel. and the hotel paid a "nuisance" claim.  The parents could point to the "award" and put the blame to the hotel rather than accepting their own responsibility.

Your commentary regarding the wall projections and feeling as if you were a "part" of the art, are exactly what I tried to capture in my images.

Comment: People may be wondering about the international legal principles that Israel is violating with its actions in the West Bank. There are two primary ones, the first having to do with Israel's commitments under the UN Charter, and the second Israel's commitments under the Geneva Conventions.

To the first, no nation may capture territory in war and claim it as its own. (Nations may only temporarily occupy territory outside their borders. Then they must withdraw.)

To the second, no nation may move its own citizens to reside on territory that is temporarily occupied through war. Doing so is a form of ethnic cleansing, which is both a war crime and a crime against humanity.

These are not trivial violations, in other words. The first is a cornerstone of International order, while the second is a cornerstone of humanitarian concern.

Comment: The laws require "the least restrictive appropriate learning environment."  The CST (Child Study Team) made up of teachers, couselors, often the school psychologist, parents, perhaps County ESD and/or state support personnel and parents work together to develop that IEP (Individualized Educational Program) which defines the placement and teaching/counseling services for the student.  

Regrettably, "mainstreaming" is a very misunderstood term.  To be sure, the concept of "least restrictive appropriate educational environment" is crucial and needs to be followed.  However, it DOES NOT mean the type of behavior described in this story needs to be tolerated.  IMO, to do so, is harmful to, not just the other students in the classroom, but, most importantly, to the student whose inappropriate behavior is accepted.  It reads to me like Edison (and perhaps all of 4J) needs to review their policies and practices.  GAry Crum

Comment: Growth or no growth is not the question because growth can't be stopped.  Managed growth can ease the pain temporarily but it has not the answer either.  Our efforts to manage growth have resulted in more costly public services, more expensive housing, congested arterial roads, social problems related to concentration of the human population, and less accountability in public spending.  There is no element of the management scheme that deals with real costs and as a result managed growth has contributed to non-managed spending and a less desirable human living condition.  Throwing ever-growing amounts of money into the government coffers has not helped bring about more accountability or solutions to the problems created by population growth.  It is time to reconsider the basic equation of managed growth and its costs.  The Eyman propositions give us an opportunity to reconsider what is important in life and to rethink the myriad of harm that our efforts to manage growth have caused.

People lie for all kinds of reasons. Some are acceptable. "How are you?" "Fine." (Even though you've just been diagnosed with cancer and are anything but fine, but you don't really want to reveal that yet in a casual conversation and ruin someone's day.)

People lie for all kinds of reasons. Some are not acceptable. "Are you working late at the office again, dear?" "Yeah, sorry." (Even though you're actually going to spend a few hours in a sleazy hotel room.)

Confirming a government official, especially at this high a level, is a very serious matter. A lot depends on it. In Mr. Sessions' case, the administration of justice itself depends on it. A lie, for whatever "reason", does not bode well for the future. It sets up a pattern of lies. It makes lying easy. It subverts justice. It destroys trust.

Mr. Sessions deserves all that justice can mete out.

Comment: Since there are what are called 'swing states', the entire country does not have to be involved.  This is the problem with the current system and why it can be defrauded.  

The United States Electoral College is the body that elects the President and Vice President of the United States every four years. Citizens of the United States do not directly elect the president or the vice president; instead they choose "electors", who usually pledge to vote for particular candidates.  The key word here, is "pledge."  

With our current technology of instantaneous communication, the Electoral system needs to be discarded and the election actually be based on the popular vote.  In addition, no exit polls, no media influencing predictions, to State totals released until the last polls are closed in Hawaii.  Only then will there be a fair election.

If banks, the military and the government can operate a closed and safe system of numbers, then so can the election process!

Comment: Exactly.  What the Ontario superior court wrote in upholding LSUC's decision to not accredit the TWU law school is that LSUC is legally authorized to make the decision, that they are certainly qualified to balance the charter rights at play, and that they did so in a thorough and fair manner that is beyond reproach.  

By contrast, although the BC law society was authorized to make the decision, it failed to engage in a thorough charter analysis.  They simply decided the matter by plebiscite, which is not a sufficient process for balancing of charter rights, and so their decision was voided.  The BC courts, consequently, had the authority to supplant their own charter analysis.

As you pointed out a while back, Alceste, it may well be that the SCC will agree with both the BC and Ontario courts.  Then the question is why they agreed to hear the appeal and what legal points they wish to clarify.  Who knows, but I suspect Ontario's interest is to defend provincial regulatory rights.

Comment: Having dealt with a large amount of real world science hiring, I have not found that equally qualified applicants have faced gender discrimination in terms of wages.  There have been cases where women were not hired for gender issues, but if hiring is done, the wage is consistent with qualifications.  It was not me making the gender-based hiring decisions but I have seen it happen and usually the reason given that women are very sensitive and because of this sensitivity would make existing male employees uncomfortable.  Now regarding the market issue brought up by Mr. Boggs, I do find it quite persuasive except perhaps in very large companies where gender issues are put under a microscope by government agencies and such.  In smaller companies, employers would be crazy to hire a man at a higher rate than a woman of equal quality would demand.  I don't know any market force for ordinary workers that would discourage employers from hiring the cheaper of two equally qualified applicants.

Comment: Nonsense. I have been prescribed painkillers post-surgery by surgeons in BC; (orthopedic in one case, urological in the other). Specialists are certainly allowed to prescribe, but they do not normally provide ongoing care; thus, for instance, a psychiatrist may prescribe anti-depressants but the patient will usually have to see their family doctor every three months for refills. Opiate painkillers are often limited to a maximum of thirty days' worth at once. That means the neurologist could prescribe 30 days worth of painkillers and then Lisa would have to go back to her incompetent family doctor.

Comment: The U.S. health care economy represents 17% of total GDP, up from 15% in 2010, and tripled since 1960 (5%). In real GDP it eats up more than $3 Trillion dollars per annum. The U.S. health care economy is a top-10 world economy by itself. To quote Warren Buffet "There's only so much of the pie it can eat." We're simply being eaten alive by the U.S. Healthcare system.  

There's zero downward economic pressure to reduce costs. Moreover, the U.S. medical model is solely procedure based and not an outcome or preventive medicine based model.  The bonuses are the fact that the leading cause of death for people under age 50 is death from opiod overdoses, physicians prescribe 80% of the world's painkillers to 4.6% of the world's population, and the life expectancies started their unabated downward arc. Throw in the fact 100,000 Americans, on average, die from hospital infections, preventable infections, mistakes, malpractice, etc. So we pay more to simply die more. Insurers win in the end.

Comment: I know it is Sunday and the only movement in the Globe and Mail office is tumbleweeds blowing through the hallways. Somehow it managed to report Avildsen's death, a man who could make a movie appealing to just about everyone, but it overlooked that Stephen Furst has died from complication related to diabetes.
Furst was one of two actors, (John Belushi being the other), who helped to make the movie, National Lampoon's Animal House, an international cinematic and cultural landmark. He played the role of "Flounder", a pleb rejected by all other fraternity houses but finding acceptance to a Fraternity on academic probation, renowned for its rejection of what was socially acceptable, and dedicated to chaos. This move arguably spun off a genre of post secondary party movies. His character-like being oft repeated. An actor easily recognizable by millions.
Sorry for attaching news of his death to this article but I thought Furst's passing needed to be mentioned as well.

Comment: Why aren't you republicans getting it. CANADA DOESN'T PAY FOR THE ROYAL FAMILY. We cover the costs of visits to Canada, and that's it. 

As to our cost, there's the Governor - General and Lieutenant - Governors. Now, replace these with elected positions. You pay the same salaries and ancillary costs, and add the costs of any elected office, from elections and canpaigning on down. 

A republic, by contrast with our current constitutional monarchy would be more expensive. 

And imagine scenarios like in BC if the decision was in the hands of an elected person, with political ties (and don't try to say the office could still be apolitical - that's a pipe dream). As the article mentions, the result would be litigation, and (more) political turmoil. 

There really is no strong argument  against our current system. The argument for change is an argument for republicanism, but without any benefit to Canada.  As this article points out, the monarchy  really is the best option available.

Comment: It's hard to imagine Canadian courts finding such a law to be constitutionally valid, especially when it comes to using public services.

They've already dealt with a case involving a niqab-wearing woman  using a public service - testifying in court.  The Supreme Court of Canada found there were certain circumstances where the accused's right to a fair trial meant the witness should be unveiled, but went on to add:

"However, never permitting a witness to testify wearing a niqab would not comport with the fundamental premise underlying the Charter  that rights should be limited only to the extent that the limits are shown to be justifiable.  The need to accommodate and balance sincerely held religious beliefs against other interests is deeply entrenched in Canadian law."

~ R v N.S [2012, SCC} at:
 https://scc-csc.lexum.com/scc-csc/scc-csc/en/item/12779/index.do?r=AAAAAQAFbmlxYWIB

Comment: William Dann - Alaska Dispatch did a series on this back when the Parnell administration scrapped ACES. They should certainly rerun and update those, but what I remember from them is that Iraq pays BP $2 a barrel for a gallon of oil pumped from their Ramadi field. That's their production credit. They then get paid a percentage of what the barrel sells for. The State of Alaska at the time of those articles was (I believe) paying $56 a barrel for BP to pump our Prudhoe Bay oil. I could be off by a few dollars, but either way, we're pay substantially more for our production credits than Iraq. Our oil is heavier and requires more processing and it's in a cold region, but Iraq is a war zone that's hotter than heck, so I'm really not sure why we're paying so much ... I suspect it has something to do with silver crossing palms and the State of Alaska's inability to grasp that it is a resource-development company that ought to have at least as much business sense as a Texas landowner.

Comment: Excellent column, thanks. Freedom of speech often isn't given enough respect in Canada. If we find the opinions voiced by these people objectionable (and they really are loathsome in this case), it's up to civil society to oppose or ignore them. The government should not be in the business of deciding what can and can't be said in our public spaces, with extremely limited exceptions.
I see the old "you can't shout fire in a crowded theater" line has already been used in the comments. People should look at what a disgrace the Schenck v. United States case, from which that line originates, was as an example of how dangerous it is to allow government to decide what is and isn't permissible to say in a public forum.

Comment: I'd sure like to know where you and Traut got your statistics on the character of police.  Doesn't match any LEO group I've observed or worked with.  I agree that people 'shouldn't' be rude to LEOs, but 'uncivil' or even down-right rude is NOT an enforceable offense, and NOT an excuse for misconduct of any sort.  No other service employment would retain a worker who felt they could be rude or resort to physical [much less lethal] force because a customer wasn't polite or appreciative.  LEOs have the ability to recourse to force, in society's recognition that *sometimes* such force may be absolutely necessary to avoid *serious* harm to the LEO or the Public.  **AND** because we trust them to be sufficiently well trained and professional in their conduct NOT to just whip it out and shoot because they're scared, annoyed, fed up with what ever, etc etc.  Is that kind of self-control quite difficult at times? - ask a waitress, or clerk, or cab driver [a job more deadly than LEO]

Comment: One of the really important things is to keep a sense of proportion. The last time I checked, Greater London had a population of about 12 million people. Given that population, the city should see in excess of 100,000 deaths a year from all causes, or about 300 per day. The deaths caused by the occasional terrorist attack are a negligible fraction of the total deaths. Terrorism is a nuisance, not a major threat.
Even the 3,000 deaths caused by 9/11 were not terribly significant; the "worst terrorist attack ever" killed about the same number of Americans as are shot to death each month by other Americans, and caused property damage (around $50 billion) equal to a fraction of a percent of American GDP. The response to 9/11, on the other hand, has killed at least hundreds of thousands, maybe millions, of people and cost the US literally trillions of dollars.

Comment: The technological revolution is more than just machines doing more and more of the things humans used to do; more than just having to find a way to support the people who have been displaced by machines. It is evolution on steroids.
The most significant aspect of the technological revolution is artificial intelligence. In my opinion, there is a threshold that once crossed will create a new dominant "species" that will be able to out perform and more importantly, out think humans at an exponential rate. It will have at its disposal all the knowledge humans have assembled and will use these resources to create new knowledge and technology the likes of which we humans cannot even imagine.
How long will it take this new dominant entity to realize that humans are not only messy, inconvenient, expensive, and more significantly, irrelevant, and inimical to its purposes, whatever they may be. The thought that humans can somehow control such an entity is the height of conceit and absurd.
